io.github.utk003.util.data.collection.slice

Class AbstractSlice<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.github.utk003.util.data.collection.slice.AbstractSlice<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - The class type of the elements contained in this AbstractSlice
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Slice<E>, Iterable<E>

    public abstract class AbstractSlice<E>
extends Object
implements Slice<E>
    A template implementation of an array-backed Slice.
    Since:
    2.1.0
    Version:
    June 11, 2021
    Author:
    Utkarsh Priyam (utk003)

         AbstractSlice(arr, 0, arr.length)
        instead.
        Parameters:
        arr - The array backing the new AbstractSlice
        See Also:

      • AbstractSlice

        public AbstractSlice(@NotNull
                     E[] arr,
                     int lower,
                     int upper)
        Constructs a new AbstractSlice backed by the specified array.

        This method limits the region of the backing array accessible by the slice to indices in the interval [lower,upper). For an unlimited slice, use AbstractSlice(Object[]) instead.

        This method throws a SliceIndexOutOfBoundsException if either index (lower or upper) is less than 0 or greater than or equal to arr.length, or if the combination of the two indices results in a negative length for the slice (ie if lower > upper).

        Parameters:
        arr - The array backing the new AbstractSlice
        lower - The lower end of the index interval accessible by this slice
        upper - The upper end of the index interval accessible by this slice
        Throws:
        SliceIndexOutOfBoundsException - If the given lower and upper indices are invalid
        See Also:
        AbstractSlice(Object[])

      • capacity

        public int capacity()
        Returns the capacity of the array underlying this slice.

        The capacity of this slice (or equivalently its underlying array) represents the maximum length of a subarray that any slice extending this slice can modify. This length is calculated as 

         array.length - slice.start_index
        where array.length is the total length of this slice's underlying array and slice.start_index is the starting index of this slice relative to that array.
        Specified by:
        capacity in interface Slice<E>
        Returns:
        This slice's capacity (for extension)
        See Also:
        Slice.extend(int)

      • adjustIndex

        protected int adjustIndex(int ind)
        Adjusts the given index to be relative to the backing array rather than relative to this AbstractSlice.

        This method verifies that the given index is valid (ie between 0 and length()), and then it shifts the index to be relative to the backing array ARRAY rather than the slice. The shift amount is simply LOWER.

        Parameters:
        ind - The index to verify and shift
        Returns:
        The adjusted index (ie relative to this AbstractSlice's backing array)
        Throws:
        SliceIndexOutOfBoundsException - If the given index is not valid with respect to the AbstractSlice
        See Also:
        ARRAY

      • get

        public E get(int ind)
        Returns the element in this slice at the given index.

        Indexing is calculated relative to the slice, not the underlying array. For example, if a slice starts at index 2 in an array, then accessing the element at index 0 (with respect to the slice) will return the element at index 2 in the array.

        Specified by:
        get in interface Slice<E>
        Parameters:
        ind - The index of the element to retrieve, relative to the slice
        Returns:
        The retrieved element, if it exists

        Indexing is calculated relative to the slice, not the underlying array. For example, if a slice starts at index 2 in an array, then accessing the element at index 0 (with respect to the slice) will return the element at index 2 in the array.

        Specified by:
        set in interface Slice<E>
        Parameters:
        ind - The index of the element to set, relative to the slice
        obj - The new value of the element

      • replace

        @NotNull
public @NotNull Slice<E> replace(int ind,
                                          E obj)
        Replaces the element at the specified index with the new element value.

        This method is identical to Slice.set(int, Object), with one exception. This method returns this Slice object, so that other method calls on the same object can be chained one after another.

        Specified by:

        Parameters:

      • reslice

        @NotNull
protected abstract @NotNull Slice<E> reslice(int absoluteStartIndex,
                                                      int absoluteEndIndex)
        Returns a new Slice bound to the same array as this AbstractSlice over the index interval [absoluteStartIndex,absoluteEndIndex).

        Though not required, it is suggested that this method return Slices of the exact same type as this AbstractSlice. An easy way to achieve this is to simply return the slice created by the constructor AbstractSlice(Object[], int, int) (or its corresponding constructor in the appropriate class) with the arguments (ARRAY, absoluteStartIndex, absoluteEndIndex).

        Parameters:
        absoluteStartIndex - The start index of the new Slice, relative to the backing array
        absoluteEndIndex - The end index of the new Slice, relative to the backing array
        Returns:
        The new Slice instance
        See Also:
        AbstractSlice(Object[], int, int), ARRAY, Slice

      • trimStart

        @NotNull
public @NotNull Slice<E> trimStart(int start)
        Creates a new (shorter) Slice object backed by the same array as this slice.

        This method is nearly identical in function to String.substring(int), except that the resulting Slice will reflect changes made by this Slice object or any other Slice object bound to the same array.

        This method is identical to calling Slice.trim(int, int) with the arguments (start, length()).

        Specified by:
        trimStart in interface Slice<E>
        Parameters:
        start - The starting index of the trimming operation, relative to this Slice object
        Returns:
        An new Slice object of the specified dimension
        See Also:
        Slice.trim(int, int), String.substring(int)

      • trimEnd

        @NotNull
public @NotNull Slice<E> trimEnd(int end)
        Creates a new (shorter) Slice object backed by the same array as this slice.

        This method is similar to Slice.trimStart(int), except that the specified index is at the end of this Slice, not the start. Regardless, the resulting Slice will reflect changes made by this Slice object or any other Slice object bound to the same array.

        This method is identical to calling Slice.trim(int, int) with the arguments (0, end).

        Specified by:
        trimEnd in interface Slice<E>
        Parameters:
        end - The ending index of the trimming operation, relative to this Slice object
        Returns:
        An new Slice object of the specified dimension
        See Also:
        Slice.trimStart(int), Slice.trim(int, int)

      • trim

        @NotNull
public @NotNull Slice<E> trim(int start,
                                       int end)
        Creates a new (shorter) Slice object backed by the same array as this slice.

        This method is nearly identical in function to String.substring(int, int), except that the resulting Slice will reflect changes made by this Slice object or any other Slice object bound to the same array.

        Simpler versions of this method exist, where the either the start or end index is taken to be the edge of this slice: Slice.trimStart(int) and Slice.trimEnd(int).

        Specified by:
        trim in interface Slice<E>
        Parameters:
        start - The starting index of the trimming operation, relative to this Slice object
        end - The ending index of the trimming operation, relative to this Slice object
        Returns:
        An new Slice object of the specified dimension
        See Also:
        Slice.trimStart(int), Slice.trimEnd(int)

      • shorten

        @NotNull
public @NotNull Slice<E> shorten(int by)
        Creates a new shorter Slice object backed by the same array as this slice.

        This method is identical to calling Slice.trim(int, int) with the arguments (0, size() - by).

        This same operation, applied to the front of this slice instead of the end, can be achieved by calling Slice.trimStart(int) with the argument (by).

        For a similar operation, extending the slice instead of shortening it, use Slice.extend(int).

        Specified by:
        shorten in interface Slice<E>
        Parameters:
        by - The number of elements to remove off the end of this Slice
        Returns:
        An new Slice object of the specified dimension
        See Also:
        Slice.trimStart(int), Slice.trim(int, int), Slice.extend(int)

      • extend

        @NotNull
public @NotNull Slice<E> extend(int by)
        Creates a new longer Slice object backed by the same array as this slice.

        This method extends the region of the underlying array that the slice can modify. In other words, 

             new_slice.length() == old_slice.length() + by
        must be true. If this is not possible (due to constraints from Slice.capacity()), then this method must throw a SliceIndexOutOfBoundsException

        The functionality provided by this method (extending a slice) cannot be achieved by any of the other slice-creation methods, as they all throw SliceIndexOutOfBoundsExceptions in such scenarios.

        For a similar operation (shortening the slice instead of extending it) use Slice.shorten(int).

        Specified by:
        extend in interface Slice<E>
        Parameters:
        by - The number of additional elements to append to the end of this Slice
        Returns:
        An new Slice object of the specified dimension
        See Also:
        Slice.shorten(int), Slice.capacity()

      • makeUnmodifiable

        @NotNull
public @NotNull Slice<E> makeUnmodifiable()
        Returns an unmodifiable version of this Slice object.

        This method is identical to calling Slice.makeUnmodifiable(Slice) with the argument (this).

        Note that method will not make this slice's elements unmodifiable. This is especially an issue for multi-dimensional slices. Once the outermost slice is unmodifiable, the inner slices can no longer become unmodifiable (except via external modification to the underlying array), as making slices (or other collections) unmodifiable creates a new object instance that must then replace the original element in the slice. Therefore, to properly make such nested slices unmodifiable, the slices must be converted in reverse: starting with the innermost slices and working outwards. One simple way to achieve this is using the Slice.applyAll(Transformation) method: for a 3D slice (ie Slice<Slice<Slice<E>>> slice), either 

         slice.applyAll((slice2D) -> {
     return slice2D.applyAll((slice1D) -> {
         return slice1D.makeUnmodifiable();
     }).makeUnmodifiable();
 }).makeUnmodifiable();
        or (equivalently) 
         slice.applyAll((slice2D) -> slice2D.applyAll((slice1D) -> slice1D.makeUnmodifiable()).makeUnmodifiable()).makeUnmodifiable();
        would return a perfectly unmodifiable 3D slice.
        Specified by:
        makeUnmodifiable in interface Slice<E>
        Returns:
        An unmodifiable version of this slice
        See Also:
        Slice.makeUnmodifiable(Slice), Slice.applyAll(Transformation)

      • sharesBacking

        public boolean sharesBacking(@NotNull
                             @NotNull Object arr)
        Checks whether the given Object is the object backing this Slice.

        This method should simply use == to check whether the given object equals the object used to back this Slice.

        In most cases, this backing object will be an array, but the argument type is Object to allow for custom implementations of Slice backed by other data structures.

        Specified by:
        sharesBacking in interface Slice<E>
        Parameters:
        arr - The object (typically an array) to check as a potential backer
        Returns:
        true if the given object backs this Slice; otherwise, false
